btrplace.solver.choco.transition

Class ShutdownableNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • btrplace.solver.choco.transition.ShutdownableNode
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    NodeTransition, Transition

    public class ShutdownableNode
extends Object
implements NodeTransition
    Model an action that allow a node to boot if necessary. An estimation of the action duration must be provided through a ActionDurationEvaluator accessible from ReconfigurationProblem.getDurationEvaluators() with the key ShutdownNode.class

    The action is modeled as follow:

    • Definition of the node state. If the node is offline, then no VMs can run on it:
      • getState() = {0,1}
      • getState() = 0 -> btrplace.solver.choco.ReconfigurationProblem.getNbRunningVMs()[nIdx] = 0
    • The action duration equals 0 if the node stays offline. Otherwise, it equals the evaluated action duration d retrieved from ReconfigurationProblem.getDurationEvaluators():
      • getDuration() = {0,d}
      • getDuration() = getState() * d
    • The action starts and ends necessarily before the end of the reconfiguration problem. Their difference equals the action duration. If the node stays online then the action starts and ends at moment 0.
      • getStart() < ReconfigurationProblem.getEnd()
      • getEnd() < ReconfigurationProblem.getEnd()
      • getEnd() = getStart() + getDuration()
    • The node can consume hosting VMs and the beginning of the reconfiguration plan. If the node goes offline, it stops hosting VMs at the beginning of the action. Otherwise, it equals the end of the reconfiguration process so that it is always capable of hosting VMs.
      • getHostingStart() = ReconfigurationProblem.getStart()
      • T = { getStart(), ReconfigurationProblem.getEnd() }; getHostingEnd() = T[getState()]

    If the reconfiguration problem has a solution, a ShutdownNode action is inserted into the resulting reconfiguration plan if the node is turned offline.

    Author:
    Fabien Hermenier, Tu Dang
